item.title: Ticket #3627 (500 Server Error For Long Posts) updated
item.dc:creator: dwdyer
item.description:
OK, maybe it's not caused by long posts because I've just had the same problem trying to post a single line comment. Switched from Opera to Safari on a whim and was able to finish posting. But Safari still had problems submitting the stylesheet change, so I don't think the browser is at fault (I realise it's a server-side problem but I thought maybe it was triggered by something in the request).

It's very difficult to pin down what causes this. I'm not going to give up on WordPress just yet, but given how frequently it is happening for me, it is very frustrating.

item.title: Ticket #3627 (500 Server Error For Long Posts) reopened
item.dc:creator: dwdyer
item.description:
I am having the same problem on my hosted site (Apache 1.3.27 on Red Hat 2.4.20-27.7smp, PHP 4.4.2) using Wordpress 2.1.3.

It does seem to only affect long posts (these were posts that I imported from Blogger using the RSS importer). The problem did go away briefly, allowing me to edit my posts, not sure if that is due to something I changed.

The reason I'm adding a comment here is because I seem to have the same problem when using the theme editor. Editing the stylesheet for the Green Marinee theme generates the same error as a long post. I am able to edit the sidebar file without any problems.

item.title: Ticket #4258 (Widgets don't show up with new integrated widgets.php) updated

item.description: The sidebar ID is being created differently, so the new code doesn't see the old sidebar. Working on a fix.

item.dc:creator: matt
item.description: If your patch doesn't fix the IE7 issue, you should create a new ticket for it, and explain the reasoning behind it.

item.title: widgets.diff attached to Ticket #4259
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy

item.title: widgets.png attached to Ticket #4259
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy

item.title: Ticket #4259 (Text & page widget improvemets) created
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
XP SP2, IE7

The errors that the attached screenshot will highlight have been around on wordpress.com for longer than I can remember. I'm surprised noone has ever bothered to file them.

In addition, please be so kind to apply the attached patch. It does the following:

  1. add an option to wpautop text widgets
  2. add an option to exclude pages from the pages widget
  3. sort page widgets using menu_order rather than by their title

item.title: Ticket #4254 (BrowseHappy Logo Shows Up for IE7) updated
item.dc:creator: Speedboxer
item.description:
Replying to masquerade:

I could've sworn we got rid of browsehappy long ago, but I suppose not. However, isn't the whole point of BrowseHappy to advocate any browser except IE? IE7 is IE still.

IE7 is a great improvement over previous IE versions. None of what's mentioned on the BrowseHappy site really applies to IE7. Plus, I'm getting really annoyed by the image. Since I am browsing happy with IE, and I always have been. If there was any browser that it should show up in, it should be Firefox, which makes my browsing unhappy. :P

item.title: Ticket #4258 (Widgets don't show up with new integrated widgets.php) updated
item.dc:creator: technosailor
item.description:
Ok, that formatting is screwed. Lets try again: 

if ( function_exists('register_sidebar') )
    register_sidebar(array(
        'before_widget' => '<div id="%1$s" class="widget wide %2$s">', 'after_widget' => '</div>', 'before_title' => '<h2 class="title">', 'after_title' => '</h2>',
            'name' => 'Full width - top'
    ) );

and 

<?php if ( !function_exists('dynamic_sidebar')
 !dynamic_sidebar('Full width - top') ) : ?>

item.title: Ticket #4258 (Widgets don't show up with new integrated widgets.php) updated
item.dc:creator: technosailor
item.description:
I can confirm that this is indeed a problem, even in the latest revision of 2.2 r5466. I tested on an existing widgetized 2.1.3 blog with a custom theme that has no id paramter, only a name parameter. The name paramter is respected in terms of name, but widget are not properly placed in the sidebars. In fact it's as if the widgetized sidebar did not exist. As an example, in this case, in %theme%/functions.php we use:

`if ( function_exists('register_sidebar') )

register_sidebar(array(

'before_widget' => '<div id="%1$s" class="widget wide %2$s">', 'after_widget' => '</div>', 'before_title' => '<h2 class="title">', 'after_title' => '</h2>',

'name' => 'Full width - top'

) );`

and in the sidebar.php:

` <?php if ( !function_exists('dynamic_sidebar')

!dynamic_sidebar('Full width - top') ) : ?>`

item.title: Ticket #4258 (Widgets don't show up with new integrated widgets.php) updated
item.dc:creator: kretzschmar
item.description: Priority changed

item.title: Ticket #4258 (Widgets don't show up with new integrated widgets.php) created
item.dc:creator: kretzschmar
item.description:
Although all Widgets are shown nicely under presentaion tab, they don't show up in the blog if you register your sidebars using names instead of the default numbers. If you use:

register_sidebar(array('name'=>'Sidebar-Column1'));

You can't use:

dynamic_sidebar('Sidebar-Top');

to show Widgets. Only by using numbered Sidebars (SIdebar1, Sidebar2 etc.) it works. (btw I am using a german locale).

item.title: kubrick-header-i18n.diff attached to Ticket #4256
item.dc:creator: nbachiyski

item.title: Ticket #4256 (i18n for Kubrick's header images and colour administration & non-js ...) created
item.dc:creator: nbachiyski
item.description:
The admin pages allowing the user to choose colours and an image for the header were not i18ned.

There was also a little bug, which prevented the normal usage of the non-js form. The patch is just a few characters, so I didn't want to dedicate another bug report. When setting the kubrick_header_image option, we should not use &, because it breaks the parsing later and the lower and upper colours weren't got correctly.

item.title: Ticket #4255 (XML parsing error: <unknown>:1:1: not well-formed (invalid token)) created
item.dc:creator: mayuxi
item.description:
What is wrong? ​http://validator.w3.org/feed/check.cgi?url=http%3A%2F%2Fmagazeta.com%2Ffeed%2F 

This feed does not validate.
    *
      line 1, column 1: XML parsing error: <unknown>:1:1: not well-formed (invalid token) [help]
          ﻿﻿<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

I just registred at FeedBurner and install FeedSmith FeedBurner plugin... and this error apear. When I deactivate this plugin - error still apear.

item.title: Ticket #4235 (Improve did_action to show information on callers.) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description:
In fact, can't we just add support for a domain argument to add_filter, add_action? Plugins that don't use it would just be added as 'unknown' for backcompat. Plugins that do would be able to specify a string 'mydomain', which could be queried providing a manner of reflection showing which plugins called what filters. Very helpful in debugging I think. Shouldn't take too long to work something up on this - will put up a quick patch to see what people think.

This might also lead to easily localisable plugin strings, as is currently being discussed on the hackers list: ​http://www.nabble.com/Improvements-to-the-WordPress-l10n-framework-tf3726667.html

item.title: Ticket #4254 (BrowseHappy Logo Shows Up for IE7) updated
item.dc:creator: Speedboxer
item.description:
Replying to Speedboxer:

In the Administration Panel, the "BrowseHappy" image shows at the bottom of the page when using IE7.

The Patch Attached uses the conditional comment <!--[if !IE 7]> to stop the image from being displayed to IE7.

Uploaded new patch that uses <!--[if lt IE 7]> instead. More future proof. (thanks, rob1n, didn't think about future proofing it :P )

item.title: Ticket #4253 (Category feeds don't indicate they are category feeds) updated
item.dc:creator: rob1n
item.description: I think this is already done. My 2.2 blog has the category title in the <title> field in the category feed.

item.title: diff attached to Ticket #4253
item.dc:creator: RuddO
item.description: Patch to make category feeds show actually category descriptions and names

item.title: Ticket #4253 (Category feeds don't indicate they are category feeds) created
item.dc:creator: RuddO
item.description:
Okay guys, here is a patch for WordPress that properly titles and describes category RSS/Atom feeds. I didn't know how to set the URL for the feed to the URL of the category, so what I'm doing is just leaving the bloginfo URL as it is, but I hope you can whip that out from your fabulous hacking heads.

This patch makes sense because of several reasons. My personal reason is that I'm running a magazine with different sections (using categories as the section) at rudd-o.com, and I'm encouraging subscriptions to the section feeds instead of the whole magazine, but the feeds themselves don't say which category they're from. Now with this patch they do.

Another thing that I'm not sure about, and I'd like a response in the form of a comment here (I'm tracking this bug via RSS): do I have to htmlspecialchars() before doing the print's "..." in this patch? The question, more properly phrased, is: if I print a get_category_name(), should I print it htmlspecialchar()red, or should I just print it out, and trust that the WordPress category administrator won't let people type random HTML? Another way of posing the question would be: if I type an ampersand (&) in the category name, what should the theme display, "&" or "&"? This is keeping me up at night, need some sleep, please help =).

item.title: Ticket #4251 (Small error in get_posts not?) reopened
item.dc:creator: momo360modena
item.description:
Not a SQL problem... just double $query ... 

	$query ="SELECT DISTINCT * FROM $wpdb->posts " ;
	$query .= ( empty( $category ) ? "" : ", $wpdb->post2cat " );
	$query .= ( empty( $meta_key ) ? "" : ", $wpdb->postmeta " );
	$query .= " WHERE (post_type = 'post' AND post_status = 'publish') $exclusions $inclusions ";
	$query .= ( empty( $category ) ? "" : "AND ($wpdb->posts.ID = $wpdb->post2cat.post_id AND $wpdb->post2cat.category_id = " . $category. ") " );
	$query .= ( empty( $meta_key ) | empty($meta_value)  ? "" : " AND ($wpdb->posts.ID = $wpdb->postmeta.post_id AND $wpdb->postmeta.meta_key = '$meta_key' AND $wpdb->postmeta.meta_value = '$meta_value' )" );
	$query .= " GROUP BY $wpdb->posts.ID ORDER BY " . $orderby . " " . $order . " LIMIT " . $offset . ',' . $numberposts;
	$query  = "SELECT DISTINCT * FROM $wpdb->posts ";
	$query .= empty( $category ) ? '' : ", $wpdb->post2cat ";
	$query .= empty( $meta_key ) ? '' : ", $wpdb->postmeta ";
	$query .= " WHERE 1=1 ";
	$query .= empty( $post_type ) ? '' : "AND post_type = '$post_type' ";
	$query .= empty( $post_status ) ? '' : "AND post_status = '$post_status' ";
	$query .= "$exclusions $inclusions " ;

item.description: You can't call a function before it is defined, namely status_header(). Will create fatal errors.

item.title: Ticket #4084 (add_query_arg urldecodes passed values but doesn't re-encode them.) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: Just so you're aware, this did break another useful function of add_query_arg, which was in easily adding arguments to param style arguments, like for wp_list_pages(). I was using it, for example, to quickly append rewrite rule query entries. So, for those who were doing a similar thing and specifically didn't want things urlencoding, the workaround is to rawurlencode the argument you pass to add_query_arg and then urldecode the whole result.
